questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with bilateral, gradually progressive conductive hearing loss and the ability to hear better in a noisy environment. She also has a history of Meniere's disease. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of otosclerosis. The history of Meniere's disease is a contraindication to stapes surgery. So the treatment of choice is Sodium fluoride (Option D).
  • All the other options are not indicated because they can increase the occurrence of vertigo once the surgery is done. All other Options were ruled out as all the procedures are stapes surgery.

Contraindications to stapes surgery:

  • The only hearing ear.
  • Associated with Ménière's disease. When there is a history of vertigo with clinical evidence of Ménière's disease in an otosclerotic patient, there are more chances of sensorineural hearing loss after stapedectomy.
  • Young children.
  • Professional athletes, high construction workers, divers and frequent air travellers.
  • Those who work in noisy surroundings. After stapedectomy, they would be more vulnerable to getting sensorineural hearing loss due to noise trauma.
  • Otitis externa, tympanic membrane perforation and exostosis are relative contraindications.
  • Stapedectomy can be done after they have been treated first for the above conditions. Similarly, stapedectomy is avoided during pregnancy.

choices.text: Dip at 2000 Hz in the Bone conduction curve
Worsening of hearing loss during pregnancy
Schwartz sign in the early stage of the disease

questions.text: Which of the following does not apply to Otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diplacusis: The Patient can hear the same sound in 2 frequencies. This is seen in Meniere's disease and not in Otosclerosis.

Other Options:

  • A dip at 2000 Hz in the audiogram is seen and is known as Carhart's notch(Option A ruled out).
  • Schwartz's sign indicates an active and early stage of the disease(Option C ruled out), and increased hearing loss is seen during pregnancy due to exaggeration of the disease(Option B ruled out).

Key takeaways:

Paracusis willisii: The Patient can hear better in noisy areas. It is seen in Otosclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ototoxic antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ciprofloxacin is not an ototoxic drug.

Ototoxic drugs:

  • Aminoglycoside-e.g., Amikacin, Streptomycin, Gentamicin-Irreversible damage to outer hair cell of cochlea
  • Loop diuretics-e.g., Furosemide, ethacrynic acid. (Act at the stria vascularis of the cochlea)
  • Antimalarials- e.g., Chloroquine, Quinine.
  • NSAIDs-e.g., Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Indomethacin.
  • Anticancer-e.g., Cisplatin, Carboplatin.
  • Deferoxamine.
  • Vancomycin.
  • Erythromycin, Tobramycin (Option A and D)
  • Ampicillin(Option B).

Key takeaways:

  • Reversible Ototoxicity- seen in Aspirin, diuretics, antimalarials.
  • Ototoxicity shows high-frequency SNHL in early stages; therefore, high-frequency Audiometry (9000 to 18000Hz) is a special test used to diagnose Ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient is suffering from recurrent episodes of vertigo, hearing loss and tinnitus for the last 3 years. The episode has nausea and vomiting along with vertigo. The episode lasts for a few hours. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vertigo associated with nausea and vomiting and lasting for a few hours, with recurrence, is the classical feature of Ménière's disease.

Meniere's disease:

  • In Meniere's disease, there is a rise in endolymph volume due to poor absorption by the endolymphatic sac.
  • It is mostly a unilateral disease.
  • Slightly more common in males. 3rd to 4th decade
  • Aetiology is unknown.
  • It is an episodic disease.

During Episode 3, features are seen:

  • Tinnitus is the first symptom.
  • Vertigo (With nausea, vomiting)
  • Hearing loss(SNHL).
  • +/- Fullness in the ear

In between episodes:

  • Tinnitus may persist.
  • Patient hears louder sounds as more louder. This is called the Recruitment phenomenon.
  • Patients can get vertigo from hearing loud sounds. This is called Tullio's phenomenon.
  • The patient has a dislike for noisy areas.
  • Patients hear the same sound in 2 frequencies. This is called Diplacusis

Disease progression:

  • Cochlear damage starts due to high endolymphatic pressure. (Glaucoma of the ear).
  • This leads to hearing loss between episodes also. This will lead to Fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Meniere's disease causes low-frequency SNHL in early stages.

Investigations:

  • PTA (pure tone audiometry) - unilateral SNHL (low-frequency SNHL in early stages). This will lead to a rising audiogram.
  • The recruitment phenomenon is positive. Tested through ABLB(Auditory Binaural Loudness Balancing).
  • The Short Increment Sensitivity Index(SISI) is positive.
  • Electrocochleography(ECOCHG)- SP: AP Ratio>30% (used for diagnostic workup of Ménière's disease.)

Treatment:

  • During the episode, anti-vertigo medications were used. E.g., prochlorperazine, cinnarizine.
  • In between episodes- Acetazolamide (diuretic)

Surgical treatment for frequent episodes of Vertigo:

A. If residual hearing is present:

  • Vestibular Neurectomy- Transect the vestibular branch of the 8th nerve to control vertigo symptoms.
  • Meniett Device - Home-based therapy: Every day, it is Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy for the inner ear.
  • Endolymphatic sac decompression surgery.

B. If no residual hearing is there:

  • Transtympanic Gentamicin Injection.
  • Surgical Labyrinthectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)(Option A):

  • Vertigo is brief (seconds) and triggered by head position changes.
  • No hearing loss or tinnitus.

Acoustic Neuroma(Option C):

  • Causes gradual, progressive unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, but vertigo is usually mild or absent.
  • Symptoms do not fluctuate and are not episodic.

Viral Labyrinthitis(Option D):

  • Typically, a single acute episode, often after a viral illness.
  • May cause sudden hearing loss and vertigo, but not recurrent episodes over the years.

questions.text: "Tullio's phenomenon" consists of dizziness induced by sound occurs in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tullio's phenomenon: Patients can get vertigo on hearing loud sounds.

It is seen in:

  • Meniere's Disease(Option B ruled out)
  • Perilymph fistula(Option A ruled out)
  • Superior semicircular canal dehiscence(Option C ruled out).

Roll Over Phenomenon is positive in the case of acoustic neuroma.

choices.text: Vertigo is the first symptom followed by hearing loss
Hearing loss is the first symptom followed by vertigo
The symptoms are in reverse order as compared to classical Meniere's disease.

questions.text: All are true about Lermoyez syndrome except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lermoyez syndrome:

  • A rare condition of Meniere's, where hearing loss is followed by vertigo. (Reverse Meniere's disease)(Other options ruled out)
  • The episode finishes within 24 hours. (BPPV-few sec)
  • During an episode, some patients can develop diarrhoea. (Very rare)
  • During an episode, some people fall without turning unconscious, this is called as Tumarkin's crisis (Rare).

questions.text: Abnormal perception of loudness is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Abnormal perception of loudness is seen in Meniere's disease. It is called the Recruitment phenomenon. It is tested using ABLB testing(alternate binaural loudness balancing test).
  • Abnormal perception of loudness is known as recruitment - a phenomenon where soft sounds are not heard, but loud sounds are perceived as uncomfortably loud.
  • This typically occurs in cochlear (sensory) hearing loss, where the outer hair cells are damaged.

Explanation of other options:

Otosclerosis(Option A) - primarily causes conductive hearing loss (due to stapes fixation), not typically associated with recruitment.

Vestibular schwannoma(Option C) - usually causes retrocochlear hearing loss, and recruitment is typically absent (can help distinguish from cochlear causes).

Otitis media with effusion(Option D) also causes conductive hearing loss, not associated with recruitment.

questions.text: The true statement about endolymphatic hydrops is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endolymphatic hydrops is nothing but Meniere's disease, which is a cochlear pathology.
  • High SISI is seen in Cochlear pathology.
  • Rollover phenomenon, faster decay time and poor speech discrimination score are seen in retrocochlear pathology(Other options ruled out).

Difference between normal, cochlear and retrocochlear pathology:

choices.text: Management of acute suppurative otitis media

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid indication of the prosthesis given in the picture
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is of Microwick:

  • Made of polyvinyl acetate and measures 1 mm x 9 mm.
  • Used for transtympanic injection of drugs.
    • Dexamethasone in a case of sudden SNHL
    • Gentamicin in a case of intractable Meniere's disease.
  • Grommet insertion is done for the management of serous otitis media and ASOM.

questions.text: All are the causes of objective tinnitus except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Meniere's disease is a cause of subjective tinnitus.

Tinnitus:

Tinnitus is a ringing sound in the ear. It is of two types:

  • Subjective tinnitus - Heard only by the patient.
  • Objective tinnitus - Can be heard even by the examiner. The Internal carotid artery aneurysm, Glomus jugulare and Palatal myoclonus are examples of objective tinnitus.

questions.text: Tumarkin's crisis occurs in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tumarkin's crisis:

  • It is a variant of Menier's disease. The drop Attacks (Tumarkin's Otolithic Crisis). In this, there is a sudden drop attack without loss of consciousness.
  • There is no vertigo or fluctuations in hearing loss. Patient gets a feeling of having been pushed to the ground or poleaxed.
  • It is an uncommon manifestation of Ménière's disease and occurs either in the early or late course of the disease.
  • Possible mechanism is deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule due to changes in the endolymphatic pressure.
